I think for both of those, what's critically important is this is where the value of our franchise really has shone through in terms of our sales capability having world-class salespeople, distribution capability in those products has truly benefited us, we believe, through this period.

I think you said – one comment just on your derivatives question. You asked if there were any other derivates that might come back on the balance sheet as a result of some market turmoil. All of the figures we've tried to show you here include both derivatives and on balance sheet positions. We're trying to show you our net economic position so that they're already included in those. There shouldn't be anything extra that's outside that might come back.
Can you comment – whether you're seeing more activity ?

In fact, as you know, during the heart of the crisis, probably three, four months ago there was a lot of money raised for distressed funds, and in fact we have not seen a lot of that money come into the market as of yet and I believe that the market's clearly looking for a bit more stability, finding an equilibrium probably for a bit more of that backlog to make its way through the system before they'll enter the market.

I think on your question on integration revenues, as you rightly point out, our view is that clearly – probably the marginal impact in terms of the impact on the bottom line of those additional revenues will be higher margin than say other businesses. So it'll be higher than our average margin. So we believe we have put in place clearly some infrastructure to execute on that, and I think as we now grow those revenues our hope is that it will be higher margin coming to the bottom line.

And then your last question on I guess payout ratio, I mean obviously we've increased the dividend this year by – we're recommending an increase in the dividend by 11% over the last year. We think that's obviously a very healthy increase in dividend, reflects our capital position, our confidence in the business. I am not sure we have any targets going forward. Obviously we will – our belief is that hopefully our business will continue to perform well and the cash flow generation of the business will be strong and that will give rise to an ongoing ability to return capital to shareholders whether through dividend or through share buyback I don't know if you want to add anything to that, Renato?
Next question.

Kilian Maier, NZB. I have a question on your statement on capital deployment. You said that you may partner with strategic third party investors to find growth. Does this mean further cooperations like the one you did with Glencore on the commodity side or is it rather issuing convertibles to gain a foothold in Asia and get GIC as investor? Could you please clarify a little bit on that statement?

Yes, I mean the, just to make it very clear, as we've said we are well capitalized. We don't have any plans to issue convertibles or any of the other capital raisings that we've seen in the industry. So we have no plans for that. The issue here is whether there are specific opportunities where some of our partners may want to put in capital into that specific business, so alternative investments is a good example were we have a very, we have a best of class capability in alternative investments and that might be an area where a large investor might want to take a big block of funds and put it in kind of side-by-side with us to invest in say the alternative funds area. That's the concept.
Thank you.
Other questions in the room? We probably have a lot of questions on the telephone.

A question on the estimation on this money market repositioning. Do I get it right that you had to protect your franchise and to avoid more outflows from the money market flows and then you bought out this bad or what became bad securities? And second question, how many funds were affected?
David, do you want to answer that?

Thank you. We have taken a voluntary decision to actually provide liquidity to our fund investors and I think it was the right decision to be taken to really protect our client franchise and also for the long-term benefit for the shareholders. There were one money market fund in the U.S. affected that was basically the main outflow.
But there remains that 3.9 billion in the books, which you – depends on the market development, could be at loss or gain, profit gain we don't know yet?

Yeah, I mean we obviously laid out for you the composition of the 3.9 billion. It's been very stable in terms of the marks on that since December. We continue to obviously effort to make progress on distributing and realizing maturities on it and obviously we're not immune to market movements, but clearly we hope to manage through that.
Shall we go to the phone? We can come back and answer more questions from analysts here.
The first question is from Mr. Jon Peace of Lehman Brothers. Please go ahead, sir.
Yeah. Hi, good morning everybody. Just wanted to say first of all congratulations on your disclosure. I think it's truly the best in-class and you've set the bar high for your peers to follow.

I wanted to ask just on the leveraged loans and CMBS exposure; can you confirm that the marks that you've taken at sort of the 31st of December and you've benchmarked on indices like the LCDX and the CMBX, so, while subsequent hits might be smaller, we could use the movements in those indices in January as a proxy for what any further charges might be?

And specifically on leveraged loans, I guess I've got a question as to whether that 10.7 billion of funded loans could include any old, difficult to syndicate positions where the write-downs could be rather more than where the pricing of the LCDX is suggesting?

And then I had a follow-up question on Wealth Management. I just wanted to know what the impact of the timing of the Hedging-Griffo closure in Q4 was on the gross margin to get an idea of the underlying run rate in 2008.

And also on your forecast for net new money, the increase of a third in relationship managers is pretty aggressive. If you can deliver on that, do you feel maybe that 6% net new money target is on the conservative side? Thanks.

Well, first of all thank you very much for your comment on our disclosure. That certainly was – our hope was to achieve that, so we appreciate your comment. Paul, do you want to address the issue of the leveraged finance, CMBS exposure? I guess kind of correlation to the indexes and how one can think about the relationship between those?

Sure. As you know very well, the exposures in leveraged finance are very identifiable. As you saw, five of our positions represent 60% of the portfolio although even there, there is a good diversity across the portfolio. Having – so we as a first measure, we really look to mark to specifics of our direct exposures. Having said that we also look back at how closely related indices have performed and in the case, certainly of leveraged finance, we can say that our portfolio is comfortably, conservatively marked relative to the relevant indexes in leveraged finance.
Also with regards to the RMBS portfolio, we can make similar statements compared to the relevant indices there.

With regards to CMBS it's a bit more complex of an issue because as you know, CMBS doesn't include the same – they doesn't includes as a homogenous asset class as, let's say an all below investment grade. In fact, it includes exposures to all different levels of the capital structure. Also as you saw, as we demonstrated the geographic diversity of our portfolio, it doesn't apply as much to the CMBX. And so what we've done there is to – so directly related to the CMBX I would say it's a very small and certainly less than 5 to 10% of our portfolio, I think you could directly compare to CMBX.

So what we've endeavored to do there to give you comfort and around our own methodology, besides looking at the single names and the specific exposures, we provide you the information on the loan-to-value ratios in each of the markets in which we operate across the Americas, Europe and Asia averaging 68% loan-to-value and I think that gives you the best measure of the relative markings on that portfolio. Thank you.

And I think as your question on the funded versus the unfunded in leveraged finance, I think they're all – it's all very high quality and there is no differential between a funded loan versus an unfunded in terms of the overall quality of that.

Both the fundeds and unfundeds are marked to fair value and I guess just one amplification on Paul's statement some of our positions are marked above the LCDX and some of them are marked below. We do that based on specific assets where we see those trading in the market so it is asset-by-asset.
Walter, the Asset Management question.

On your question on Hedging-Griffo, Hedging-Griffo has added two basis points in to the gross margin in the fourth quarter. Now you need to know these are performance fees and they're paid semi-annually in Hedging-Griffo and we stick currently to that 6% growth rate in net new assets.
Two points in the fourth quarter, less of an effect annually, obviously in terms of the annual number?
Yeah.
Thanks very much.
Next question on the phone?
Your next question is from Ms. Fiona Swaffield of Execution. Please go ahead, Ms. Swaffield.

Hi. Can we talk bit more about capital, because if you look at your disclosure, you talk about other adjustments having hit the Tier 1? I think it's quite a large swing. It looks like you lost about 70 basis points. It does mention pension actuarial gains. So could you tell us whether that is permanent?

And then also could you talk about risk-weighted assets and whether as the CMBS matures or the warehouse get older and also on leveraged finance, whether you are going to get quite a lot of RWA growth? So how confident are you about the Tier 1 ratio in that kind of environment? Thanks.
Renato, do you want to address the question on that?

Yes. In fact, it's, the amount you see there in the tier 1 ratio is a correction of something that happened in the equity. Basically, the equity went up because we had to re-base our actuarial assumptions, which resulted in a higher equity amount actually to be booked directly into the balance sheet. Now under the capital requirements from the regulators these movements are eliminated in the tier 1 calculation. So, therefore you see this amount of – it's roughly a 1.1 CHF 1.2 billion that you have as correction item other. But that first has – that has first increased, so to say, our book equity and has been taken out for regulatory capital, that's the explanation for that amount.

I think with regard to risk-weighted assets question, I don't think we see any particular reasons for risk-weighted asset growth to – in terms of some of the things you mentioned about some of the existing positions. I think we just – we think there are gong to be some good opportunities and we'll grow our risk-weighted assets, or shrink them according to the opportunities that we see out there.

Absolutely, maybe just an additional remark on the risk-weighted assets growth. As you can see on page 54 of the report, the whole growth basically comes from the change in the market risk equivalents, which basically, Wilson has explained to you from the impact that the VaR had on our ERC.

What I am trying to understand is, you've got quite sizeable net exposures in CMBS and leveraged finance. If you don't basically distribute those in 180 days, I thought that starts to come onto your balance sheet. Are you saying you're 100% confident you'll distribute it or are you saying that there's some things you've done that means it won't come into risk-weighted assets?
Yeah. Maybe I can take a stab at answering that. With regards to the CMBS, it's already fully-funded.
Okay.

Marked-to-market, fully funded. With regards to the leveraged finance, if as more of the unfunded commitments become funded that would have an increase in our risk-weighted assets if we are unable to continue the success we've had at the selling down the portfolio.
Okay. Thanks so much.
Next question on the phone?
The next question is from Mr. Matthew Clark of KBW. Please go ahead Mr. Clark.

Good morning, just another question on the CMBS exposure. I believe you've got quite a large gross exposure and we've seen the indices widen out massively so far this quarter. Could you just talk firstly about your hedging strategies there and whether you expect to benefit from an overreaction of hedges versus cash marks or whether that doesn't provide any comfort for you?

And then secondly, in terms of your strategy on managing down that portfolio, whether you are inclined to hold them and wait for prices to improve or whether it's a case of you'll just get them off your books, if you can shift them at current market prices? Thanks.
Paul, do you want to address that?

Sure and Wilson, please feel free to hop in. I would say, certainly with regards to our success at selling down the CMBS we have had good experience, as you saw in the fourth quarter, of selling down the CMBS exposure. It is, as I said earlier, relates to all different parts of the capital stack and we have had a good success at finding interested parties in those loans. Remember as Wilson pointed earlier, the bulk of the exposures are to high quality assets, income producing most of them, as well the bulk of it is office property.

I guess, a couple of further points on that. As Paul said, we are shifting these assets at current marks. We did make good progress in Q4. I'd also caution you on applying CMBX, although it is visible and that's useful to people, it does not really reflect our portfolio very well. It really only applies to, as Paul said, about 10% of our asset mix. It's also important when you look at that index that by far the largest portion the capital stack are the AAAs, which have moved much less violently than the other parts of the index. So I think you need to be very careful in trying to extrapolate from that index to our positions. We do look at that as well as other cash positions as specific assets values when we are doing our mark-to-markets but it is not – it is certainly not a one for one tracking device you can use for our portfolio.

Perhaps I could just follow-up and ask if you could give a bit more detail about whether you've had more success selling down the higher rated or the lower rated tranches from the CMBS capital, stack as you describe it?

Yeah and I guess I'm going to respond that we've with the disclosure we've already provided, we've already received the calls and emails from our trading desk saying we've disclosed more than anyone in the market has disclosed. At some point it becomes quite confidential proprietary information. So I think with that I'd rather not comment on specifics of where we are selling down our portfolio.
But it has been across the board. We have sold things in different regions and different parts of the capital structure.
Okay. Thank you.
Next question on the phone?
The next question is from Mr. Huw Van Steenis of Morgan Stanley. Mr. Van Steenis, please go ahead sir.
Good morning. First, can I echo the earlier comments on some of disclosure, which I think is very helpful?

Two points, first, in Asset Management you've still got about 3.9 billion of SIV notes and the like and you mentioned you are seeking to hedge those positions. I mean, to the extent you can, can you share any color on how successful you've been in Q1 or should I really read that as that is effectively the net exposure going into the quarter?

And then secondly, going back to capital, I am struck that your ERC has remained broadly flat in the Investment Bank despite the VaR gapping out in the quarter and I think ending VaR is up another 23% again. To what extent in your discussions with regulators or even your accountants have there been sort of heated discussions about whether may need in the future to revise your ERC or whether you are truly confident that that rather than VaR is an appropriate measure that regulators and accountants as well as yourself will look at to manage the business?
Okay. Well, first of all thanks for your – again, thanks for the compliment on the discloser. I appreciate it.

On the Asset Management positions, I think as we said, we've disclosed very clearly where we were at year-end. Obviously, we – as you can imagine we've continued to effort that. We're not going to update sort of on where we are right now in terms of that but you can imagine obviously that our objective is to continue to distribute and to reduce the exposures there.
We also I think as Wilson mentioned we do certainly have some hedging on against that and so we continue to hope and believe that we'll be able to manage through that.
Wilson, do you want to answer the question on ERC?

Sure. ERC is not really driven by VaR. We built it in part so that we would get away from this backward looking feature of VaR. That can lull you into a false sense of security during a bull market and VaR for the same positions in '04, '05 would drift down where ERC stayed stable. It's been a more useful guidepost for us to measure risk. It's really designed around how to handle crises and that's why it was useful during this period.

As you saw in our detailed business lines we have cut some significant risk positions and that's why ERC has gone down. I think that's actually a better reflection of our true risk position today than VaR which is really much more volatile depending on market data.
Next question on the phone?
The next question is from Mr. Dirk Hoffmann-Becking of Sanford Bernstein; please go ahead, Mr. Hoffmann-Becking.

Good morning. A question on the Wealth Management outlook. You stated that declines are reducing there, exposure to high risk assets and in particular structured products. Is this a development you expect to continue into 2008 and to what extent does that effect your "One Bank" revenues forecast for 2008?

The second question is on compensation in Wealth Management where you say that you have lower performance related compensation due to an increase in deferred share-based compensation. Does that mean you have a change in the bonus model for Wealth Management?
And last question is around the money market fund, does that affect the Wealth Management business in any way?

I would just start. I'll ask Walter to address maybe in specifically, but maybe just to make a couple of general points. I would just reflect that actually the private client, client base for us and I think generally for the industry it remains quite healthy. They not have had a lot of exposure to these – to a lot of the issues that have come up over the past eight months, and they remain a very healthy client base and so that I think is a positive going forward. I'll let Walter make some more specific comments.

In terms of the – in general on the performance related compensation as you mentioned for Wealth Management, for the whole firm as well we actually increased marginally our – the share portion of our compensation this year in order continue to get better alignment between our management and our shareholders, between our employees and our shareholders and to get better alignment with kind of longer term goals of the firm. So, we did marginally increase the deferral portion of our compensation, which did impact Wealth Management as well.
Do you want comment on the outlook in terms of clients' exposure to structured products and how that may impact the business?

Sure. Obviously, we are not first of all immune to markets and market movements. That's clear. But when it comes to like structured products, there are obviously lots of structured products, which provide great returns in maybe uncertain markets and we have for example, we call them, "Total return with capital protection." So structured products can really help in the current market environment and I would expect that the structured product program we have ongoing for many, many years will continue, but it is obviously subject as well to overall market opportunities you have. And we have lots of initiatives like the managed investment products for example, which should help to guide through this maybe little bit of slower markets.
And just to your last question, the money market fund issue had no impact on any private clients.
Okay. Thank you.
Next question on the phone?
The question is from Mr. Kian Abouhossein of JPMorgan. Mr. Abouhossein, please go ahead sir.

Yes, hi. First of all your CMBS exposure, could you talk about your hedges and if I look at the 27 billion of macro hedges and I look at your gross write-down versus your net write-down, is it fair to say that half of the 27 billion hedge related to leveraged finance, half to commercial mortgages?
Okay, Wilson, do you want to answer that?

If you are looking at that CHF 27.1 billion it's probably, actually more about two-thirds in those corporate credit sectors I mentioned, the non-investment grade and the crossover credits and about third in mortgage linked indices.
Yeah. But in terms of applying these hedges to your gross exposures of leveraged finance and commercial, is that also good indicator that two-third, one-third?
No. I'm just giving you a breakdown of what asset classes those hedges are in overall, some of those hedges are held specifically within the business and some are held in a more accrual basis.
Okay.

We also made the point; I think Wilson made the point that those are just index hedges. We've got single name hedges and so that's not – that's not the entirety of the hedging as well. So I think it's – notwithstanding the extensive disclosure we've given, I think it's going to be difficult to probably reengineer back into exactly what is offset against what.

And if I looked at the CMBS exposure warehouse, it's roughly equal to your underwriting volumes in 2007, which I'm a bit surprised about in terms of size on your books. Can you explain why there is roughly a one-to-one equation?

I'll take this one. This has been a growth business for us for many years. We have successfully syndicated a lot of business. I don't know that particular ratio that you are talking about. That does surprise me a little bit, but we have in the past successfully syndicated all this. We have been bringing down this position pretty rapidly and we continue to make good progress in it.

And lastly on monolines, first of all your 2 billion monoline exposure or counterparty exposure, does that include basis trade risk, counterparty? And secondly on the wider topic, do you see Credit Suisse as a supporter of bank wide support for the monoline industry?

On your first question, measuring gross exposure for monolines is something that we've done across the bank. That includes both direct counterparty exposure as well as inventory position that may have a monoline wrap. Sometimes we actually have two or three layers of protection, but if it does have a monoline wrap in it, we counted that on a gross nominal basis, but as I said our economic exposure because of reinsurance and other trading positions, those hedges more than offset that gross exposure.

Thank you. As to your other question obviously we haven't really been very involved because we don't have much exposure. We don't have much exposure to the monolines. Clearly, we would be supportive of having a healthy functioning, monoline guarantee industry out there. That is it is important for the business, so we are certainly supportive of that. Since we don't have any material exposure, we haven't been very involved in the discussions.
Okay thank you very much.
Thank you, next question on the phone?
The next question is from Mr. Derek Chambers of Standard and Poor's. Please go ahead Mr. Chambers.

Yes, Derek Chambers from Standard and Poor's Equity Research. Again thank you for the disclosure. One element that you are disclosing rather differently from others is the element of your exposure that's in trading based portfolios. If we look at those in the RMBS and CDOs you had more or less breakeven or even profit in the first nine months and then losses in the fourth quarter. I wonder if you just say something about how we should think about that. Was it that you had residual positions which had to be written down or was it difference in timing between hedging strategies, sort of basis risk and are these losses things that can move up and down in future or are they lost forever?
You want to answer it?

Maybe I can take that. You know, I think it's a combination. It is difference in timing. There were timing differences, as Renato actually pointed to some of these earlier in the third quarter statement. But also as you saw we took down a significant amount of the assets. So part of taking that down there were some P&L effects related to taking down some of the categories.

You pointed to the fact that we've disclosed it somewhat differently than others and I think that's right with regards to the entire RMBS portfolio. We did disclose, as you saw, Alt-A and as well as the Prime pieces and most significantly you saw the significant decrease in that Alt-A piece which is probably most relevant.

And that probably had the biggest impact on those P&L numbers that you mentioned. For instance, one of the things that we had said, as you mentioned, is in the subprime area I mean we – even on a year-to-date basis in subprime we're probably breakeven to plus, minus, around breakeven in subprime. So we've not had any even net write-offs in the subprime area. So that really is – those numbers that you see are from the whole stack as Paul mentioned and you can see the dramatic reduction in the Alt-A segment, which is something that we felt was very prudent to have done in the fourth quarter. We will see how that plays out?
And disclose it to you.
Thank you.
Next on the phone?
The next question is from Mr. Jeremy Sigee of Citigroup. Please go ahead, Mr. Sigee.

Good morning. Thank you very much. Two question, please; one on asset management. You had very strong revenues in the line items above private equity gains and mark-downs. Ex- those underlying gains, underlying revenues look very strong. Do we take those as a recurring level or are there any funny items in there that we should be aware of because they look very strong?

And then second question is on non-staff costs across several of the divisions which you touched on and I wonder if you could just come back to it to give us a bit more detail about what some of the items are for example the corporate center has about 111 million extra non-staff cost in it in the quarter, Wealth Management has a big chunk more as does the Investment Bank. So can you talk about what's in those extra costs and how quickly they fall away?
David, you want to address the issue of the Asset Management underlying revenues

Sure. I think as also outlined by Renato, I think we have increased our recurring revenues over the course of the past quarters. There are no funny items in there. There are some performance fees in there but it just shows the growth in our recurring revenues and hopefully given the markets, we do expect strong recurring revenues in the future as well.
Can you quantify performance versus management fees?
I think we have given a lot of details today in our disclosure. I think we don't want to go into that relationship, but certainly it's a smaller part of that number.

Also I think I would just emphasize, Jeremy, the importance and the strength of the alternatives business within that. It is performing extremely well and continues to be a best-in-class capability for us. And I think that's a real underpinning to the strong performance in 2007.
On your question around G&A, do we have an answer to that, Renato?

Yes, there was a specific question on the corporate center side. I mean, corporate center G&A expenses are pretty stabilized. Not so that we suddenly spend much more money at corporate than in the quarter before. The main item that makes it a little bit more volatile is that we have adjustments in there for inter-company adjustments. So basically, we have to eliminate certain profits taken down the line on the group, but that can be volatile. This is the normal accounting rules you have in order to – in the way you show corporate center. In general, we can say that our non-compensation costs have been pretty well contained in 2007. We've seen that overall in the bank. Actually, we went down in the non-compensation costs and it's definitely our aim to further improve that.

The increase, you've gone sort of kind of 2.1, 2.2, 2.3 and then it's a jump to 2.7 in the fourth quarter. Are you saying that's kind of intra-year volatility and we should just focus on the full year?
Yes.

I would probably be more – yeah, I would say it's more instructive to focus on the full year. To be honest with you, Jeremy, we may have to come back to you with a detailed answer, but it's probably a timing – sounds like a timing thing. I mean in general, we continue to be focused on and pleased with the progress that we've made on our non-comp costs in terms of – and the prospects for continuing to manage those.
That's great. And you've given us targets for the future as well, so that's understood. Thank you.
Thank you. Next question on the phone?
Your next question is from Mr. Christopher Wheeler of Bear Stearns. Please go ahead, Mr. Wheeler.

Yes. Good morning, everybody. Couple of questions on slide 30, if I may, which Wilson kindly showed us. The first one is, being a boring accountant, I'm trying to tie up the write-downs in the 2P list, because obviously you disclosed 2.2 of write-downs in the third quarter, and you have here 2 billion. So I'm just – for the full year, we seem to have lost about one point – I just wondered, is this in other structured products or it was fixed income, actually just clarify that. I'm sure that's a simple question.

The second question really comes back to the subprime mortgage exposure. You were talking about having 4.3 billion net. I'm assuming that's net of hedges at the end of the year. I mean that's something like 6.2 billion at the end of the third quarter. I think at the end of the third quarter, Renato was really firm in saying that the exposure was de minimis. So I'm just trying to get my head around, was there other hedges that was part of the other 27.1 billion you mentioned there that were set off against that subprime? It doesn't really indicate the mortgage indices that led you to say that. Perhaps you could give us a view as to whether you can give us the net, having taken those indices – all those hedging indices off.

And then a third question on capital: I was just looking at your slides you gave us at the Investor Day last January, when you talked about 8 billion of excess capital. If I ask you to do that slide again I'd just be interested what you think you'd say your excess capital is at the moment, perhaps at this point in time and maybe what you think it'll be at the end of the year?

And then finally, just to Walter, 12 billion was an excellent result for net new money in Wealth Management in the final quarter. Can you give us any indication as to how the leaching in Asia helped that, given I think that was all completed by August? Thank you.
Okay. A lot of good questions. Do you want to start with the reconciliation of the period write-downs?

Certainly. On the full year, you saw on that slide 30, that we had write-downs of CHF 2 billion, and as Wilson mentioned, we can understand how there'd be a reconciliation issues from what we disclosed in the third quarter. And the difference can fully be explained by the fact that there were timing differences. Again, Renato mentioned some of those timing differences in the third quarter in that they were hedges that we've had on our portfolio that had gains in the first half that weren't reflected obviously in the third-quarter numbers that we had mentioned. In addition, to make the data comparable with our peers, we've looked at it on a net basis and we've also added back embedded carry in those positions, which all reconcile to the CHF 2 billion total write-downs.

Just on your drill-down into the CDO questions, the numbers we've shown you there are the net exposures within the CDO area to subprime. As we mentioned we also have some of these index hedges overall, which help mitigate risk, and I'd say a third component that underlined our comments at the time was sort of our mix of the quality of assets where we tended to hold the higher tranches and the longs and be short some of the more junior tranches as well as being we think better positioned in some of the vintages. We're in better performing vintages overall on our long side. So there are a couple of other components that bled into that disclosure in Q3.

Well, you didn't disclose anything in Q3, Wilson, I guess that's the question. You just said de minimis. I'm just trying to say, are you really saying that the 6.1 did come down because of that mix you mentioned, to virtually nothing?
What we're saying is at that time, we had some significant macro hedges and we also had a good blend within that portfolio so that from a trading perspective we thought the exposure was de minimis.
Okay, thank you.

Yeah. And you can see obviously as we said the subprime performance in the fourth quarter was probably approximately breakeven and for the year, so as a result you can see that we did not think it was exposure that – there was not material exposure and there clearly wasn't.
Renato, you want to address this question of the excess capital; 8 billon of excess capital? I don't know what -

If I remember correctly the slide you referred to was when we discussed the debilitory force and what would we potentially do with the excess capital? Just a matter of fact, if I remember correctly that was 4 billion because the other 4 billion was already in the calculation in there. At that time the consequence – what we did was we announced the share buyback program, which took care of the 4 billon already in the second half of 2007. Now how this slide would look like at the end of this year is very difficult to say. As Brady said I think we're prepared to take opportunities, if there are opportunities out there. At the same time we have of course also to watch marketing and market developments and make sure that we have a prudent capital management for the group as a whole. So, at this point in time, I think it would be pretty difficult to already foresee on how this slide would look like at the end of '08.
Walter, you want to address the issue of the net new assets in the fourth quarter and Asia's role in that?

Just to give you a little bit of flavor in net new asset distribution. Very happy about Asia, it contributed almost 50% to it and we had very strong inflow from the Middle East and from Europe and we had a little bit of a seasonal slowdown in Switzerland, which is always related to tax payments and amortization of mortgages. So that gives you little bit of a flavor about the split.
Thank you, gentleman. Thank you.
Next question on the phone.
The next question is from Mr. Elie Darwish of Exane BNP Paribas. Please go ahead, Mr. Darwish.

Yes. Good morning. This is Elie Darwish from Exane BNP. I would like to just come back on slide 38 and ask you to what extent did you hedge the CHF 3.9 billion of securities transferred from money market funds to your own balance sheet at the end of Q4 actually, and if you – actually, there are hedges that can be used to reduce this gross exposure?

On the share buyback, this is my second question, I would like you to clarify whether the CHF 8 billion program is effectively going to be completed by the end of '08 or are you now more flexible regarding the end of this program? Thanks.

I think with regard to – maybe I'll just take these two quickly. With regard to the hedging on the 3.9 billion of securities, as Wilson mentioned, we do have some material hedges against that, but it's not completely hedged certainly. And obviously as you mentioned in any hedge, there are few hedges that are perfect hedges. So, we do have some hedging against it. As I mentioned it's been relatively stable in terms of valuation since early December. But we do have some hedges there clearly.

In terms of the share buyback, I think you probably said it correctly. We established the 8 billion program last May. By the end of the year, we had effectively executed on half of that program. It was originally a program through 2010. We had thought that we might actually execute that in '08 and I think now, I think, you probably put it well. We're going to be flexible in responding to business opportunities and market conditions in order to see how that progresses.
Okay. Thank you.
Next on the phone?
The last question is from Mr. Derek De Vries of Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead, Mr. De Vries.

Yes, thanks. I have a two questions for Wilson Ervin since we have you on the phone. The first relates to correlation trading. And I was wondering how happy you are with your models and are you reducing your exposure to this business in light of what could be sort of a several standard deviation event in terms of downgrades? And then also if you can maybe give a comment on the systematic risk from correlation trading?

And then the second area is, I was wondering if you could walk me through the pros and cons of your approach to offloading your leveraged finance exposure to Harrah's and say what this will mean for reducing your exposure in leveraged finance going forward? Thanks.
Wilson, why don't you answer the first on correlation trading? Maybe Paul you could answer the issue on the distribution.

Hi Derek. With the respect to correlation trading, as we showed you our overall CDO positions are relatively moderate, and this does include correlation trading related to subprime assets. In general, we think we're positioned good for opportunities going forward. We think this is a time where having a small position enables us to be much more active with customers and we see good opportunities in two way trading there.

With respect to your question on systematic risk, I would not say correlation trading per se is a big driver of that. I think what we are working through now is a big credit adjustment, so it's really more the nature of the big credit and liquidity positions that are the systematic challenge now. I don't really think it's correlation trading per se.
Great.
Paul, want to answer the question on the...

Yes, I think it's a short answer because as we said earlier we don't comment on specific positions, names. Relating to your question on Harrah's in particular, I think what we can say is the desk has been extraordinarily disciplined about selling down positions and opportunistic about doing so and it is no exception with that position.
Okay.
I think on the analyst side any further questions here in the room? Any last questions that anybody would like to ask?

Okay. If not, we really appreciate your attendance today. I think we're going to take a couple minute break and then come back in to address any questions from the media if that's okay. Thank you very much, everybody.
Question-and-answer session for analysts is now over. We will now continue by taking questions from media representatives.

If everybody wants to take a seat, we'll get started. I'm sorry we've already – it was a particularly long presentation because of the extensive disclosure that we've done. So, I apologize for keeping you here that long, but with that we are happy to open up for any questions from the media.
Yes, back here.
from Reuters. I'm kind of wondering why you hesitate, in a way, to give us an outlook on 2008?
Does it work? Yeah.

Is it – while on the other hand you seem quite upbeat on the mid-term? Is it just because you have got the feeling that market will be quite volatile or the market – the visibility on market is low, so you do not want to say much about the next six months or so?

Well I think to be honest, I'm not sure what value it gives for us to predict what the markets will be like in 2008, I'm not sure if we sat here last February, 2007 that the predictions would have been very accurate for the what happened 2007, so I'm not sure that predictions can be that helpful, I mean what – I think what we have tried to lay out is the fact that we think – we have a business model that's quite resilient across almost virtually any either more challenging markets or less challenging markets and that we have by virtue of our geographic diversification or business diversifications; we think we're very well positioned for that.

I think it's just hard – it's hard to know exactly how markets will proceed this year. I am probably a little bit more optimistic than some in terms of seeing improvement in the markets this year but I think it's very hard to know how markets will proceed, so we don't – so we haven't spent a lot of time trying to give a very precise view on how we think the markets will proceed in '08.
Yes?
I have one question about capital deployment, which – with which kind of strategic party or investor may you partner to finance growth in Investment Banking and Asset Management?
Yes. Would you mind just mentioning your institution?
Yes, you mentioned strategic partners, which kind of funding of...?

Okay. Yes. Okay. I think in general as we mentioned, we are very well capitalized. So in terms of our basic capitalization, we feel like we're well positioned. What we have look at is the possibility of actually raising capital into specific business opportunities. So I mentioned the alternatives opportunity as one. There might be some other businesses where capital could be used to supplement and grow our businesses. They would tend to be some of the more capital intensive businesses. So, I think alternative, the alternatives business is one where we think having some partnership capital would be helpful, but potentially also some of our more, our higher capital using businesses within the Investment Bank could also be areas that we would consider.

Could I just add one sense which I think is very important to understand? This is not capital that adds to our existing capital of the corporation, but is capital that goes specifically in the areas, that Brady just mentioned. So it's not a capital increase from a company point of view.
Finance some projects or...?
Specific or to take advance of opportunities, it is almost like side-by-side capital to realize certain growth opportunities.
Next question here in the middle.

Thanks. Finanz und Wirtschaft. Could you probably state the figures to the collaboration revenues in percentage of the total for the target of 2010? And the Basel II effects, could you lay out some of the details, please? And maybe for the fair value adjustments, can you state some more details where the securities are held in which divisions?

Sure. With regard to the percentages as we mentioned that the 5.9 billion that we showed is about 16% of this year's revenues. And as we said we want to take that to 10 billion by 2010, I don't think we – I don't think it'd probably be appropriate for us to give a specific percentage of overall revenues. I think it will – I think it will be a higher percentage of our revenues over time. I am not sure that we can predict precisely the revenue, the revenue number say in 2010 for the whole firm. I do think that actually these collaboration revenues, the integrated bank revenues will be – we will be able to achieve those, obviously assuming kind of normal market conditions, but those I think will be more – they will be less subject to fluctuations in the market and business conditions. So probably a higher percentage, the 10 billion will be a higher percentage in '10 than the 5.9 was this year.
Basel II, do you, Renato, want to address that?

Yeah. I think the most obvious and simple explanation is that Basel II provides a much more comprehensive way of risk weighting assets you have on the balance sheet. And through that basically, we got higher amounts of risk weighted assets through the Basel II calculations than we had under Basel I. That was particularly true in higher risk areas like in Investment Banking while in other areas like in corporate and retail banking, which was actually benefiting from Basel II because certain asset classes like mortgages in Switzerland for example are less risk weighted. So the Basel II effect came mainly from a revaluing of the risk weighted assets in total out of which of course we have to have a certain percentage of capital underlying those risk weighted assets.

One amplification of that, within our ERC model we had already made most of these changes. So we'd already weighted those Investment Banking businesses more heavily than the Private Banking businesses. So in the sense, this aligns the regulatory capital view of our capital with our internal view.

Maybe I can also give you an indication of what that really means in us keeping the same Tier 1 ratio that means de facto that we will have some 4 to 5 billion more capital that we have to retain in the organization due to Basel II, everything else equal.
Do you, Renato, want to address the question on fair value adjustment? Your question on fair value was specifically...?
Oh, yes! Which fair value? We have fair value of course in whatever Wilson has explained in on the risk side was that your question on how this was done?
There were some fair value adjustments on some securities...?

You mean on our own debt? Yeah, the fair value methodology is of course not only something you want to apply on your asset side, but also potentially on your liability side. So, that we are fair valuing our liabilities to the market the same way we do it for the asset and that of course provides us with a meaningful hedge also from the point of view that if spreads in the market go out, become higher the funding costs of our businesses become higher and therefore they have a disadvantage of – out of the increase in spreads that they can get in the market. At the same time, by fair valuing our own debt, this comes to our benefit. So, it's a compensation for this deterioration in the spreads for the overall businesses. Basically, the benefit of these fair value appreciation of our own debt were given back to those users so to say of funding, which I mentioned to you earlier is done purely on the centralized treasury basis. So, they basically get in a way compensated for these more expensive funding cost they have in the market.

Now, it's extremely important to understand that we – and there we are differentiating quite a lot to some of our peers. We have a very strict cost allocation methodology for the funding we are giving to the front office. So we are reflecting the market prices so to say in our allocation of funds and our fund transfer pricing. So in straight terms, we are not subsidizing any businesses by the Group being able to fund cheaper than they would be able to fund in the market, which of course is not – an additional element of our risk management culture that basically the front has to think twice if they want to go into higher risk area because they have some cheap funding.
Next question?

Two questions more. Wealth Management first. You hired quite a few new Relationship Managers, on the other hand net new money grew quite – higher than analysts had expected. Could you give us an indication to what percentage portion let's say newly hired managers brought – added to this net new money?
And second question would be, do you have any indication that money was kind of brought across the street from your competitor to you in the Wealth Management business?

Obviously, the hiring came in the last quarter, so that will have a lagged effect in terms of new relationship managers, but roughly we calculate between 40 and 50% of new hires contributing to the net new asset bottom line and the rest comes obvious from existing and from "One Bank" collaboration, so on and so forth.

And I do not comment obviously on flows, where they are coming from. I think what is the most important thing is the relationship managers and this is what I wanted to stress before are extremely attracted by our platform, you know contrary to what some people say, because it just gives you – being a relationship manager, you have so many instruments to really provide solutions to your clients through the "One Bank" and that will eventually boil down in a lot more net new assets. That's really how it all plays together and where the assets are coming from, I don't care as long as they come to us.

But I think clearly we think given the strong capitalization, the fact that we've managed much better with a lot less volatility makes it a very attractive platform for clients to come to, so we are very positive on that.
Yes?

Swiss Radio, just to follow-up you were talking about 1000 new people, where are they going to work? You said you want to focus on ultra high net worth individuals that was a normally a focus of UBS, so it looks like you are going to attack here directly your concurrent.

And then another question; in the USA there are investigations going on, the FBI, is Credit Suisse there also involved in this investigations and do you agree that authorities should bring light in the turbulences in the U.S.?
Do you want to start, Walter with the issue on the 1,000 new people in ultra-high net worth?

Okay. The 1,000 new people how they are going to be spread obviously, the emerging markets, the high growth areas will be a major focus. It's going to be Asia, it's going to be Latin America, it's going to be Middle East but as well in Europe, we are still adding people on the onshore, in our onshore businesses, where we will probably add less this year in Switzerland. It's a pretty saturated market, but here we will work through upgrades. Then, what was the other question?

Ah! Ultra High Net Worth individuals. It's obviously a very competitive environment, but we do believe that with our capabilities we are especially well suited to enter that segment more aggressively. And it is already proven now with the revenues which we're generating out of that segment has gone up quite dramatically, that's why we think we can really make a big difference in terms of value proposition.

I think on the investigations that you mentioned; we obviously won't make any comment on any specific regulatory or other investigations. I would just say in general what you can see in terms of our exposure to say, the subprime area and the residential mortgage area in general, I think is indicative not just of our positions, but also how active we were with clients. So for instance, in 2006, which was the full year before 2007, when everything – all the problems hit, we actually originated about 40% less mortgages during that year because we weren't as comfortable with the credit quality and the structures and so our hope is that to the extent that there are issues in the market, we will hopefully be less susceptible to those because of the fact that we actually were less active in those markets during that period of time.
Yes?

a free-lancer. I have just one more question about that. When was at the exact moment in time when you decided to reduce your subprime exposure and what was the reasoning? Did you see it in your economic risk capital model or what was the reason why you reduced – started to reduce this exposure?

Second, you made some interesting comments about bonuses. I didn't understand exactly how this works in that traders will have to give some of the share, of the benefit they earn, some of their bonuses in which years. How does this work?
And third, if there is a consolidation in the global finance industry, what kind of role could Credit Suisse play? Thank you.

Well, I think, the first question about the exact moment in time I mean, as I mentioned to you there were – obviously, it's been a process over a long period of time. It's involved a lot of people throughout the bank: our risk management areas, our business areas, all the way up through management. So, you know, I'm not sure there was a point in time where we simply made a decision that the markets were not markets that we wanted to be involved in. But as I mentioned, it even starts with – in 2006 we cut back a lot of our origination activity just because of the fact that the kinds of credits and the structures that were – some speculative structures were being used in the market and so we actually reduced our involvement in that.

So that was one point, I would say late in 2006, I think, in December for instance, we actually lost money in our residential mortgage business that was kind of the very early beginnings of the subprime area. We at that point actually cut our business down in about half from where it was at that point. So, we took some very dramatic measures and we were pretty consistent in our views on that market over the rest of the year.

And as you may remember, it's been a very odd crisis in the sense that there have been storms and periods of blue skies. So December, was very difficult, 2006 in the markets January and February the sky was blue again, March was difficult, April and May things were okay again and then in the summer things really started in earnest and some people sort of think it all just started in the summer and the truth is there have been various periods, and so we were very consistent throughout that I think, in our view that these were going to difficult markets and we needed to try to position ourselves defensively for them.

On bonuses, the comments – I think the comments you're referring to is the specific comment that we made to a structure that we have in the bank and it particularly relates to traders. And the structure that we have is such that in a given year they are obviously paid a bonus based on what they produce. But we take a portion of that bonus and we effectively put it into an account, which is given to them on the basis of their future performance. So, if in the next year they lose money in their trading book or they lose money in the activity they're undertaking; they lose a portion of last year's bonus and we typically carry that out for two extra years. So, effectively a bonus to someone when it's paid in 2007 is at risk of being lost in 2008 and 2009, if their performance in that business doesn't – loses money let's say.

And so, that's something that we think gives people a much longer term horizon about – now we have a number of people on that system, but we're actually trying to – we're trying to make sure that both through share, through making sure employees hold shares in the company and just trying to come up with ways to get people to not only be aligned with shareholders, but also be aligned in terms of a long horizon and thinking about how to manage the business and structure, which we think is healthy for the business.

You mentioned your last question was on consolidation. We have been, I think we are very happy with the businesses that we are in: Private Banking, Asset Management, Investment Banking they are the high margin, high people content businesses that are high growth. We have, I think, great franchises in all areas, but also terrific opportunities to grow. We see a lot of opportunity to operate them on an integrated basis. And so we see a lot of organic opportunity ourselves. And as you say, I'm sure there will be continued consolidation and changes in the market in general. I think we are very comfortable with our business and our strategy and that we think we can be very successful and create lot of value for our shareholders and serve our clients well through this structure.

I have a question considering slide number eight. I think it's not fair to South of America the Latin America what you are showing there, it's minus 19% for all Americas. Can you say and how much the South or the Latin America is performing, so we can see how bad United States are?

Second question, is considering this discussion around your money market fund in Asset Management. You're buying back assets out of this fund. Why only for institutional clients? Aren't there comparable assets in products for private clients as well, which you should buy back also?
Third question is all this hedging which you have done, how expensive are they? I think at this moment in time a lot of competitors want to hedge their positions also. It must be very expensive.

And my last question is considering your trading in the Investment Banking there you have in fixed income trading you have made losses. What kind of losses are these? I don't understand this. It's on – in your financial review on page 21. Thank you.

First of all Latin America is a terrific region for us. I mean we have great business down there. We have probably the leading franchise in Brazil. As some have mentioned we actually acquired a business, Hedging-Griffo, to really make us the leading Investment Banking, Private Banking and Asset Management firm in Brazil. That's been a terrific market that's been growing extremely well.

We have a great franchise in Mexico. We have very strong businesses throughout Latin America. So, as you say it certainly has been – actually 2007 was a great year for our businesses in Latin America and very strong. So you are right to point out that the reduction in the Americas as a whole doesn't probably do justice to the strength of the business in Latin America.
I think in terms of the money market fund issue, David, you want to answer that?
On the comment that was made; we haven't made any differentiation between Private Bank clients or institutional clients. They were treated equally, so no preferential treatment to any client.
To you on the hedging side, Paul or Wilson?

I will mention that quickly. Back at the risk investor day last year, we talked about the cost of hedges. We spent I think, it was about CHF 500 million on our hedge program during the good times. That meant that it was already baked into our results during that period. Those were expensive hedges during the good times but they have been very helpful in these more difficult times. As you said, it's also difficult at times in the current markets to put on good hedges but we benefited from having these hedges put on early.

In fixed income, in think, I am not sure what losses you are referring to. If you turn into slide 17 in the presentation or as you mentioned, page 21, I think you'll see that although there was a reduction in revenues of 24% from about 9.6 to 7.3 in fixed income and obviously the areas, that in structured finance – structured products and leveraged finance were lower revenues certainly and as well not as good progress in commodities and investment grade but there were some very strong areas such as rates and derivatives, foreign exchange and emerging markets which more than offset it, resulting in a full year of profitability pre-tax income for our fixed income division.
Thank you. Another question?

. I have two questions. The first is that you mentioned that you – in 2006 you started to reduce your exposures in residential mortgages although afterwards there were some good months again and bad months, so it was up and down. How was that within the bank? Was there also contradiction, resilience against these moves? Were there are lot of discussions about that, maybe people who suggested to go again into this market? That's the first question.

Second question is you mentioned that the credit and structures started to be unhealthy from a certain time. What exactly was unhealthy, what were your indications or the indications that the credit structures weren't healthy any more?

I think on our first question, I mean it's a very good point. It's one of the things that we've pointed out is that oftentimes even when you know what the right thing is to do it also takes a lot of resoluteness to actually make it happen and so a good example, certainly residential mortgages, but an even better example might be the CDO business.

We were one of the leaders in the CDO business from in the early 2000s as Wilson mentioned in his presentation and then we basically, substantially de-emphasized that business. In fact some of our people who were doing that left to go other organizations because they didn't agree with our approach to that. And certainly during that period of time, I can tell you that 2004, 2005 people internally were saying, "We are missing this opportunity, this is crazy, other people are making a lot of money in the CDO space." And we said, okay, but we don't think it's the kind of business with the kind of risk profile that we want to be in.

But clearly that's exactly the kind of – that's exactly the kind of opposition that you can come up against. so that's oftentimes I think that's the more difficult thing is not just realizing what is the right direction but actually making sure that you take that direction.

I think with regard to the credit structures on the residential side Wilson may be able to help, but it was things like – I mean all the things that you've read about in terms of structures where people would have no interest payments, no principle payments for long periods of time and structures which clearly increased the speculative nature and also increased the credit risk.
I don't know if you have a specific, but...

Yes. There were structures like that that became popular in the U.S. There was also much reduced amount of disclosure and so you did see an increased amount of fraud in some of these pools. There were even structures where not only did you not have to pay interest but you might be able to basically amortize up the principle amount, so called Option ARMs. So there were a number of things where people did get a little exuberant during the bull market and that's obviously proved to be a bad decision in recent months and we've tried to steer a much steadier course and maintain stricter standards in our underlying pools and that's been helpful. It did cost us some business over the course of last year and early this year but it was a good decision.

I think it's fair to say we did receive some of those early warnings signs. We own a servicer, a loan servicer called SPS, a small loan servicer but that gave us really early warnings signs of some of these issues in the market.
Any other questions? I know it's been a long session so...

One question, which I already put in I – Mr. Blumer answered it but I didn't meant that Asset Management did for itself, didn't serve private clients and institutional clients the same way. I wanted to ask again if there are also in products for the private clients are there assets which are problematic – as well as problematic as they were in this money market fund that you should buy them back also? Perhaps more considering for the Private Banking sector?

Well in general we have no assets, which have such kind of components in it with maybe some small exceptions and there we talk one to one with the clients and engage obviously to see how we can help. But in general, we always make a risk assessment, a very careful risk assessment with our clients and advise them according to the risk profile of the client what he can buy and what he can't buy, and we obviously do as well the necessary risk disclosures, so we are pretty safe on that side.
Okay, I think with that we will bring the session to a close. Thank you very much for your attention and for the long – for staying here so very long. Thank you very much.
